The skill provides guidance for git worktree operations using standard git commands (git worktree add, list, remove, prune). All detected patterns are false positives: backticks are markdown code delimiters, path sequences (../worktrees/) are standard git worktree conventions, and cryptographic/hash keywords refer to metadata field names, not actual crypto operations.

content.user_title: Manage git worktrees for parallel development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple branches simultaneously requires switching contexts or stashing changes. This skill provides expert guidance on creating isolated git worktrees for parallel development without disrupting your current workflow.
actual_capabilities: Create git worktrees for parallel feature development
List all active worktrees with status information
Clean up worktrees for merged branches
Manage isolated hotfix environments without disrupting current work
Review pull requests in isolated worktrees
Guide path conventions and worktree organization
limitations: Cannot auto-commit or push changes in worktrees
Does not resolve merge conflicts automatically

best_practices: Create worktrees outside the main repository directory to avoid nested git repos
Use consistent naming conventions for worktree paths based on branch names
Remove worktrees for merged branches regularly to avoid clutter
anti_patterns: Creating nested worktrees inside the main repository directory
Leaving orphaned worktree directories after branch deletion
Checking out the same branch in multiple worktrees simultaneously

faq.question: What is the difference between git worktree and git branch?
faq.answer: A branch is just a pointer to a commit. A worktree is a full working directory attached to the repository.

faq.question: How many worktrees can I create?
faq.answer: You can create as many worktrees as you need, but each branch can only be checked out in one worktree at a time.

faq.question: Do commits in worktrees affect the main repository?
faq.answer: Yes, all worktrees share the same git history. Commits made in any worktree are visible to all other worktrees.

faq.question: Is my data safe in worktrees?
faq.answer: Worktrees are regular directories. Your code and files are safe, but remove worktrees using git commands to clean up references.

faq.question: Why is my worktree showing as prunable?
faq.answer: A worktree appears prunable when its directory was deleted manually. Run git worktree prune to clean up stale references.

faq.question: Can I use worktrees with cloud development environments?
faq.answer: Worktrees work locally. For cloud IDEs like Codespaces or Gitpod, consider feature branches or separate clones instead.
